post_body: To the characters we make that are women:   I love you. You deserve to be wrong and right and face the consequences of being either one.   be ugly or pretty without it being ensconced with another character‚Äôs development i hope you hate and love things and there‚Äôs not a moral superiority there within the conflict.  I hope the things you care about are specific and personal with genuine reasons that arent what‚Äôs simply expected of your role in a character.  I hope your attractiveness in body and mind isn‚Äôt just a character trait that just happens to make people gravitate to you. I hope you initiate attractiveness be aware of it and take advantage of it when you decide to.   I hope you are written with your own intentions and selfishness even if those intentions are selfless.   I hope you make mistakes and struggle in how to fix them whether it be bc of the inward self or the feelings of others.

post_body: Poison from the Same Vine  Chapter Four  Word Count: 5.5k  Pairing:  Bruce Wayne/Batman x fem!OC  Rating: 18+ eventually  Warnings:  Creator chooses not to use warnings in this chapter.  Author Note: My laptop has died and trying to format the screenshots I made of their texts is proving to send me over the edge. I swear there‚Äôs more.     August Twenty-first  There had been small introductions as time passed. With his secret still safe and kept locked away I proved to be more of an asset with what knowledge I carry from years of consuming stories. But there were some failsafes put in place: Only information that was necessary would be given freely I wouldn‚Äôt talk about the Gotham Gallery unless they showed up and I reserved the right to not say things in the event that it could seriously damage a timeline. You felt the last one was a bit of a copout but after plenty of pleading Batman acquiesced.   In the wee hours of the morning Bruce is still out galavanting around the Gotham skyline. He‚Äôd managed to stop two muggings and a robbery this evening. While he is working I am learning to man the computer with Alfred. According to Bruce it was time I made myself useful if Alfred insisted that I be around the property as he liked to keep a closer eye on me.  But like I‚Äôm helping Batman at the Bat Computer. That‚Äôs fucking dope.  After midnight though it had been oddly quiet. Batman is following a lead down at Gotham Dockyards. The warehouse catwalk that Bats was perched on left him fairly exposed if a rogue flashlight pointed in his direction.  His cowl and earpiece were synced together and able to do text-to-voice when he was in stealth mode. As the newest member of Team Bat I am given a direct line to him. A bonus during my training. Alfred asked me to fire off a message to him to test it out.     <!-- more --> I toss my phone onto the desk in a huff narrowly missing a few controls and I sulk back into the chair. Alfred shoots a look over his shoulder with a chuckle. ‚ÄúIt appears that the sync between your phone and the suit works well.‚Äù  ‚ÄúApparently‚Äù I deadpan. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs an ass.‚Äù  ‚ÄúHe may be my lady. But he‚Äôs the financier for this entire endeavor and as you pointed out with your knowledge he is the world‚Äôs greatest detective. Try to not let him get to you.‚Äù  When Batman‚Äôs feed scans out over the warehouses I can see that there isn‚Äôt much going on thankfully. He‚Äôd gotten a tip from a small-time drug dealer that there was going to be a movement of product near Wearhouse Eight around two this morning.  The mob had been pushing boundaries a little lately and as more wiseguys were getting locked up courtesy of the caped crusader they were trying to get more creative on how they moved their supply in through and out of Gotham.     Though he would come home restless on the quieter nights his adrenaline not having had any sort of cathartic outlet I am silently grateful when he would come home unscathed. At least on Alfred‚Äôs behalf.  Not that Alfred wasn‚Äôt already having me put some of my newly learned medical skills to good use on the days where he would need IVs or mild first aid but I couldn‚Äôt fathom how someone would willingly put themselves through this day in and out.  But I‚Äôm also not a masked vigilante and that‚Äôs not entirely a thing where I‚Äôm from.     ‚ÄúAlfred‚Äù Batman tapped the earpiece in his cowl.  ‚ÄúYes Master Bruce?‚Äù  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm revoking her contact privileges.‚Äù  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll do nothing of the sort. It‚Äôs a second form of safety that I for one am exceedingly grateful to have in the event that there‚Äôs an emergency and I am indisposed.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhen have you ever been that indisposed?‚Äù  Alfred scoffs ‚ÄúThat is entirely beside the point Batman. She‚Äôs another set of eyes and ears when you are out at night. Over time I think she could be an integral part of The Batman‚Äôs operations. Give her time to adapt.‚Äù  ‚ÄúShe made you those scones you like didn‚Äôt she?‚Äù  ‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶yes.‚Äù Alfred chuckles and sends an updated schematic to Batman‚Äôs wrist communicator. ‚ÄúRegardless instigating her as Bruce Wayne in the daylight shouldn‚Äôt preclude you from her retaliation when you‚Äôre out as The Batman.‚Äù  Air passes quickly through Batman‚Äôs nostrils in a mild snort before he jumps to a rooftop. ‚ÄúSounds like you‚Äôre on Chase‚Äôs side over mine.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI am not taking sides. I am merely making an observation.‚Äù  There‚Äôs a hum of acceptance rumbling in his throat while his eyes scan across the docks. The only sound he can hear is the mild lapping of water against the piers; and after his earlier run ins perhaps it was best the night had gone quiet.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to give it another twenty minutes. Maybe the intel wasn‚Äôt good. It‚Äôs quiet and it doesn‚Äôt look like anyone‚Äôs around.‚Äù     ‚ÄúTHE SHIT DID YOU SAY THAT FOR?!‚Äù I shout helping to haul Batman‚Äôs body across the table after he‚Äôd staggered off of his bike. ‚ÄúYOU STUPID FUCKING‚Ä¶!‚Äù  ‚ÄúChase‚Äù Alfred reprimands in warning while he retrieves the medical kit from across the lobby of the cave. When he returns he sets me in motion to check vitals.  ‚ÄúFucking stupid‚Äù I mutter ripping the cowl off his head and tossing it aside. While I shine the pen light in his eyes and check for a possible concussion I keep berating him quietly.  ‚Äú ‚ÄòOh it‚Äôs so quiet out. Oh it‚Äôs so calm‚Äô.  ‚ÄúWho says that you moron! Nurses say it? ER gets slammed. Cooks say it? Biggest rush of the night. Cops say it? Whole fucking precinct is hopping. And you think it‚Äôs a good idea as one guy in his pajamas flouncing around at night to say it while you were in the middle of the mob‚Äôs territory?  ‚ÄúFucking stupid.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs enough Chase.‚Äù Alfred‚Äôs voice cuts into my monologue. ‚ÄúHelp me get the suit off now.‚Äù  It‚Äôs a whole process to get Bruce out of the suit on a good day. There‚Äôs an order that the pieces are put on and taken off. He‚Äôs got it down to a science and can get ready in under five minutes if he is truly pressed for time.  But now? It is unbearably difficult to get him out of his ballistic skin because he keeps writhing on the table and his suit is slick with blood.  ‚ÄúMaster Bruce stay still‚Äù Alfred commands as he fills up a syringe. It‚Äôs one of the cocktails he has included in the kit over the past few years with something for infection.  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have time for this‚Äù I hiss between gnashing teeth. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm cutting him out of the pants. I can‚Äôt get to whatever‚Äôs bleeding!‚Äù  ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you dare‚Äù Bruce growls. ‚ÄúJust get me out of the suit.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get this off you! You‚Äôre not exactly helping and I haven‚Äôt taken Batsuit 101 yet you asshole!‚Äù  The trauma shears do not make a dent through the tactical fabric and armor much less cut it open.  ‚ÄúWayne Tech‚Äù Bruce laughs while he tries to peel off his gauntlets with Alfred‚Äôs help. ‚ÄúPricey. Made to withstand‚Ä¶‚Äù  You snatch one of the scalpels from the tray and start slicing into the fabric. Bruce is frozen dumbfounded and Alfred takes this opportunity to administer his cocktail into Bruce‚Äôs now exposed thigh.     ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt move.‚Äù  While my eyes are locked onto his each word is punctuated with an edge as sharp as the tool in my hand before I cut my way from his waist to his ankle. With some assistance from Alfred in peeling blood-soaked tactical fabric from sweat-slick skin my eyes begin evaluating the damage. A four-inch slash runs along his inner thigh from where he had a run in with a switchblade.  To his credit Batman was spartan-kicking a guy off of the steel catwalk in the warehouse when the guy took a piece of Batman with him as he fell.  ‚ÄúEvaluate Chase.‚Äù  Your eyes snap up to Alfred whose stoic demeanor gives me enough of an inclination that Bruce isn‚Äôt in any mortal danger. Regardless I sit stunned for a beat before I physically shake my head and stare back at the wound.  ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be serious‚Äù Bruce groans sitting up on his elbows. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to just let her take over?‚Äù  You blink twice before irrigating the area and wound ‚ÄúYeah what he said.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThis is an unfortunate but necessary component to working with The Batman‚Äù he nods before walking to retrieve a suture kit. ‚ÄúHe will be injured from time to time. He bleeds. He needs time to recover and heal. More time than those bloody comics of yours allow.‚Äù  He washes his hands and opens the kit for me. ‚ÄúClean yourself up. I‚Äôll slow the bleeding down with a tourniquet. But you‚Äôll be fixing him up because you can and because you must.‚Äù  Any argument dies on my tongue and I take my leave to scrub my hands. Over the sound of rushing water I hear Bruce arguing with Alfred presumably over my insertion into the medical aspect of tonight‚Äôs events. The exchanging of words and the fervor with which Bruce seems to voice his displeasure are enough to sow doubt in my mind.  ‚Äú‚Ä¶because you can and because you must‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚ÄúAlright Alfred. I can stitch him up once you‚Äôve cleaned the wound out. You did say my sutures look better than yours‚Äù I try to make light of the situation before me with false bravado.  The butler nods cleans the wound and situates a towel across Bruce‚Äôs lap.  ‚ÄúI will be close my lady. But you need to act quickly.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI know‚Äù I agree clinically. ‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt start now I won‚Äôt jump to it when it really counts.‚Äù  He hums quietly to himself. ‚ÄúType of stitch you plan to use? Remember your patient doesn‚Äôt listen and tends to not follow doctor‚Äôs orders.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI can hear you you know‚Äù Bruce turns his head to side-eye Alfred. ‚ÄúPretending I‚Äôm not here isn‚Äôt going to help.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking an interrupted vertical mattress suture will work that way if he pulls a stitch the whole set isn‚Äôt shot. And maybe a little on a zig-zag to minimize scarring?‚Äù  ‚ÄúIn this particular instance I‚Äôd be partial to the continuous subcuticular. But your logic is sound enough. You‚Äôre using monocryl so it‚Äôll be absorbed over time assuming he doesn‚Äôt rip his leg open.‚Äù  You nod pull the needle through his skin. Bruce jumps and slams his hands on the table.  ‚ÄúBefore you growl at her again‚Äù Alfred reaches across him to the tray. ‚ÄúI have another shot to administer.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThanks for the anesthetic Alfred. Don‚Äôt feel like getting stabbed more than once today‚Äù the vigilante‚Äôs dark humor ebbing into the conversation.  You peer up over Bruce‚Äôs leg at Alfred and ask ‚ÄúWhy the subcuticular? Doesn‚Äôt that hurt?‚Äù  ‚ÄúOf course it does.‚Äù  Bruce closes his eyes and rights his head on the table ‚ÄúYou make it sound like you stitch vengefully on purpose.‚Äù  ‚ÄúOnly when you deserve to learn a lesson Master Bruce.‚Äù  The needle lances through his skin after I tie off another suture and he flinches.  ‚ÄúHow long until the anesthetic kicks in?‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhat anesthetic? I administered a tetanus shot‚Äù Alfred mumbles sitting down at the nearby chair to monitor my work. Bruce cracks an eye open at him and scowls.  ‚ÄúI suggest you harken back on the training you have to regulate your own pain and come to terms with it while Chase is here with us. She‚Äôs a part of this team now Master Bruce.‚Äù     With only two stitches left to go my row is neat and nearly looks like it could be photographed for a textbook. Alfred occasionally interjected a word here and there to either make me pause or propel me forward but all in all this wasn‚Äôt the worst experience. I mean I am sewing up Batman but‚Ä¶you know.   Wearing his blood up to my elbows a mistake of wiping my brow with my forearm caused a smear of rust to mar my face.  ‚ÄúTwo left Bruce. How are you doing?‚Äù the words quiet but not unkind.  ‚ÄúFine‚Äù he all but grumbles from up the table.  In truth I feel poorly about how Alfred‚Äôs done him dirty tonight. You didn‚Äôt intend to start a family dispute nor did I relish the fact another human being was in pain at the expense of my needle. There was a point where I tried to reach for a vial so that I could administer local anesthetic near the wound but Alfred tutted at me and asked that I get back to work.  ‚ÄúHe will not always have the luxury of pain medication my lady. He can relearn that lesson tonight too.‚Äù  Not once did Bruce twitch or flinch after that while I sewed him up; his eyes closing and more than likely putting his body into a meditative state. An apology fell from my lips when I thought I had dug too deeply with the needle halfway through the gash but still he hadn‚Äôt moved.  With the final suture tied off and cut the scissors and needle are dropped into the tray with a loud clang disturbing the mild peace that had settled over the three of us. Alfred‚Äôs keen eyes had watched my handiwork every step of the way and I feel them upon me again when I stand to stretch.  ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you head upstairs‚Äù he stands behind me with a gentle hand on my shoulder ‚ÄúAnd shower for the night Miss Chase. I‚Äôll see to Master Bruce and get him to bed.‚Äù  Autopilot has me nod in agreement or resignation. I don‚Äôt think I could tell which at this point after the last of the adrenaline left my system. All the same I head upstairs and shower until the rust in the runoff runs clean.     The past week had afforded me a courtesy while I worked nights for Batman: I‚Äôd been afforded a guest room at Alfred‚Äôs behest and Bruce‚Äôs grunted agreement. God it had the plushest mattress I‚Äôve ever slept on. Tonight though? It calls to me after I get out of the shower and I want nothing more than to collapse into it and wake up sometime after noon like Wayne tends to do. But my mind returns back to the tone of voice Bruce used and his adamant refusal for my assistance.   It continues to replay in my mind over and over until I find myself downstairs swiping my keys from the hook in the garage and then I‚Äôm leaving the property. The city lights streak over my windshield as the first tendrils of dawn creep at the horizon. The pedal to my car flattens out my car glinting through what remains of the city‚Äôs shadows; that‚Äôs when I find myself inside the living room of my apartment.  Pieces of the night are hazy while others maintain exceptional clarity. How I drove here is a little foggy: I don‚Äôt really remember the traffic or the actual driving nothing outside of the speed grounding me to reality.     It‚Äôs not that I owe him anything. I don‚Äôt. Telling myself that I don‚Äôt over and over is becoming a mantra I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd put into daily practice. A memory of that phrase being repeated the whole way home surfaced briefly before it dissolves into another where I am stitching his leg up with the same thing going through my head.  It shouldn‚Äôt bother me that he‚Äôs hurt or that he might be pissed at me. He‚Äôs the one that keeps galavanting out at night regardless of the risks regardless of how well versed he is in martial arts. Though he‚Äôs still around the age of a freshly graduated college kid. He‚Äôs young. He‚Äôs human.  It shouldn‚Äôt pull at my mind and heart.  But it does.        ‚ÄúYou will go down to that shop and apologize to her‚Äù the butler‚Äôs normally calm demeanor is far more bristly this afternoon.  Wayne pushes himself up in bed and winces the stitches pinching as he moves. ‚ÄúYou both said that I need to rest so that I can heal and now you want me to get out of bed and go down there? Mixed signals at best.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThat woman stitched you up better than I do‚Äù he snaps ‚Äúand she fled out of here after her shower before I could tell her as much. This is your fault.‚Äù  ‚ÄúMy fault?‚Äù his voice still rough with sleep. Alfred rips open the curtains and Bruce shirks from the afternoon light. ‚ÄúHow is this my fault?‚Äù  ‚ÄúMaster Bruce I‚Äôm saying this with all due respect but you need to figure out if you want her to be here or not.  ‚ÄúYou cannot keep changing your mind pending the situation deciding if you find utility in her participation here. Miss Chase is navigating your mood swings and indecisiveness as best she can.  ‚ÄúYou are already enough of a liability being a part of my life Alfred‚Äù Bruce growls and leans forward. ‚ÄúHow many times did people take shots at you to get to me growing up? You think having another person around is going to make that more manageable?  ‚ÄúI know how much you want this to work because it‚Äôs a means of keeping me safe. I can wholly understand that but‚Äù he looks around the room exasperated ‚Äúwhat I do isn‚Äôt safe. Protecting Gotham doesn‚Äôt put me into a line of safety.‚Äù  Alfred sighs ‚ÄúI understand that Master Bruce. But in this singular circumstance having that additional shroud and information would be of more benefit than your pessimistic foresight.  ‚ÄúFurthermore while I understand the delicacy of the matter and the circumstances of this operation rather acutely shouldn‚Äôt it be her decision?‚Äù        From the back room I hear how gravel tears into the fabric of Cujo‚Äôs voice and the sudden cease of work on the shop floor. There‚Äôs murmuring back and forth between men it‚Äôs all I can do to finish throwing towels into the dryer before going to investigate what‚Äôs going on.  ‚ÄúYou got a lotta nerve showing up here‚Äù Cujo gnashes out shoulders square to the intruder.  ‚ÄúLook‚Äù a pacifying baritone floats over amped up testosterone ‚ÄúI just need to talk to her.‚Äù  I round the corner and see all four guys creating a wall between me and the perceived threat who happens to sound a lot like Bruce.  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what the hell you did to her‚Äù Irish points a finger in Wayne‚Äôs direction. ‚ÄúThe past two days she‚Äôs be borderline silent without so much as a fucking sarcastic comment. And we know that she went to your place after work the other night.‚Äù  Jax crosses himself and I take quiet measured steps into the room. ‚ÄúYeah. And if you‚Äôre gonna come in here and tell us that your butler is the one that made her upset you got another thing comin‚Äô. That dude‚Äôs the sweetest to her outside of us.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI came down here to apologize to her‚Äù Bruce tries to placate.  Not that Batman couldn‚Äôt take all four of the shop guys Bruce Wayne is a bit of a pansy with a lot of the storytelling I‚Äôve been doing as of late. He doesn‚Äôt want to have to cross lines if he doesn‚Äôt have to.  While I do happen to get a little glee from this part of the song and dance routine and much to my better judgment I rest a hand on Cujo‚Äôs shoulder and wedge myself through.  A quirk of a brow and attitude settles into my voice ‚ÄúThen apologize.‚Äù  ‚ÄúLook can we go somewhere and talk?‚Äù  Irish takes a step forward ‚ÄúWhy you afraid to say what you wanna say in front of us?‚Äù  ‚ÄúYeah a little‚Äù Bruce allows and I chuckle to myself. He makes a point to shift from one leg to the other and looks across the room. ‚ÄúI should get friends like you have Chase. Jeez.‚Äù  When I take another step forward Jax puts a hand on my elbow. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to go with him girl. He can stay right here if you want; or we can throw his bitch-ass out.‚Äù  I laugh and pat his hand. ‚ÄúFunny as that would be I think he‚Äôd rather do his groveling without an audience. Or you four scaring the shit out of him. I‚Äôll humor him this time.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôll text you if he needs his ass beat. Chances are he wouldn‚Äôt be able to get to his car before you got to him.‚Äù  ‚ÄúDamn straight.‚Äù Dozer glares daggers at Wayne before begrudgingly turning to his client and going back to work.  There‚Äôs a wave of relief that cascades down Bruce‚Äôs body before he holds the front door open for me to pass through.  We walk for a few minutes in silence the humid June air is stifling in the Gotham heat. I can‚Äôt help but let my mind wander for a few minutes thinking about how nice it is that the shop is in the East End and only a block from the Sprang River; how there‚Äôs a really comforting cross breeze coming up from the water. The guys would probably prop the door open today to help with the heat.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been doing some thinking‚Äù Bruce‚Äôs voice drops into its more comfortable Batman range. ‚ÄúAnd I need you to listen.‚Äù  When I stop along the river walk he follows suit and I cross my arms in front of my chest. ‚ÄúI need to listen? I thought this was supposed to be an apology. Because if it is you suck at this.‚Äù  His eyes narrow and he bites back ‚ÄúAre you always this much of a pain in the ass?‚Äù  I feel something twist in my gut a vice that ignites a guilted rage at feeling sorry for him the other night. Why do I feel empathy for this asshole? He‚Äôs a privileged ass with more issues than I‚Äôm equipped to deal with. Why did I have to get stuck here of all places.  ‚ÄúYou know what Bruce? I can just walk back to that shop and those guys will never let you walk back in again.‚Äù  He smirks and stuffs his hands in his pockets. ‚ÄúThey could try. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôll go the way they would think it should.‚Äù  ‚ÄúOh come off it‚Äù I groan. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to go after a bunch of innocent men trying to protect someone who‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚ÄúNo you come off it‚Äù he growls back forcefully shedding his suit jacket and draping it over his arm. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try and play games. This is real Chase. All of this; all that I do is my reality every single day. Don‚Äôt you dare stand there and try to pull some lofty stance on how I should conduct myself.‚Äù  Bruce leans his forearms on the stone wall and gazes across the water towards The Bowery.  ‚ÄúWhat I do isn‚Äôt safe Chase. I‚Äôm trying to get you to understand that.‚Äù  ‚ÄúAs the person who‚Äôs got some of the mythology in my skull pretty sure I know what you‚Äôre about.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs different when it‚Äôs real. A veteran knows war differently than someone reading about it in a history book.‚Äù  Intrigued I move closer and lean on the wall with him lowering my voice ‚ÄúI can appreciate that statement.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIn your talks with Alfred has he brought up what happened when I was twelve?‚Äù I shake my head and he nods without looking at me eyes still focused across the river.  ‚ÄúAlfred had been waiting for me to finish school. I had French and Japanese lessons after school that semester‚Äù he ponders thoughtfully.   ‚ÄúThe French lesson was only three blocks away and we usually walked it for the sake of keeping up appearances as Bruce Wayne. He‚Äôd park out front of the building walk to the school collect me and walk me to my lesson. We‚Äôd done it for a few years and I didn‚Äôt think much of it. There‚Äôd always been some level of hesitancy or feeling as if I was always being watched. The Son of Gotham was always under a microscope; I still am to a degree.  ‚ÄúOne day in February‚Ä¶right before my birthday actually I came out to the courtyard and Alfred wasn‚Äôt there. He‚Äôd never not been where he was supposed to be. My teacher snatched me by my shoulder before I could take off to find him and dragged me inside. Guess Alfred and I owe her for that one.‚Äù  ‚ÄúGood‚Äù the word blurts out of me before I can catch myself turning to stare at him. ‚ÄúAt twelve? What would you have been able to do Bruce? Alfred wouldn‚Äôt have wanted you to do something so rash.‚Äù  Bruce looks over at me with a knowing expression. ‚ÄúHmpf. Sounds like a lecture I‚Äôve gotten from him once before. What makes you say that?‚Äù  ‚ÄúBecause I wouldn‚Äôt want Ayla to do something stupid like that.‚Äù I clear the lump in my throat and turn back to the water.  ‚ÄúWhat happened?‚Äù  ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd been jumped and taken hostage when the robbers realized I wasn‚Äôt with him. When he refused to give me up or act as bait they beat him. They‚Äôd had him for a few days before they cut him loose after GCPD had put out a bolo and done a press conference on it.  ‚ÄúAlfred had a broken rib a concussion a couple broken fingers‚Ä¶all because they wanted to get me.‚Äù  A heavy sigh escapes him bowing his head and closing his eyes. ‚ÄúSpeaking of our recent history anyone that gets close to a Wayne ends up beaten bloody or dead. What if that‚Äôs something that Alfred and I don‚Äôt want for you?‚Äù  I mean he‚Äôs got a point. Assuming that this isn‚Äôt psychosis and I‚Äôm not in a coma or hell and this genuinely is my reality now‚Ä¶is that something that I‚Äôm willing to risk? What if there‚Äôs a way to go home and I end up permanently getting stuck here or I can‚Äôt get back because I‚Äôm hurt or kidnapped?  But again what if this is the way life is going to be? I don‚Äôt owe him anything. But something keeps whispering to me that this is where I‚Äôm supposed to be I guess. That this is what I should be doing.  And that‚Äôs stupid.  ‚ÄúConsidering the sheer absurdity of it all I don‚Äôt really think that matters. Look if you want me to help fine. If not that‚Äôs also fine. I get it from the logic of it all. But you‚Äôve been an absolute jackass to me lately‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚Äú‚Ä¶I know‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚Äú‚Ä¶and all I‚Äôm trying to do is help out and do the things that you and Alfred ask of me but you just brood and grouch over it because ‚ÄòI like to jump around in my underoos in the dark and I am the night‚Äô. And God forbid anyone else come to help out‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚ÄúChase‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚Äú‚Ä¶because I have to do everything alone and I‚Äôm sad and broody. Newsflash mister everything you‚Äôve done or will do is because of family so‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚Äú‚Ä¶I‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù  My mind shorts out mid-ramble and I blink a few times almost as if I‚Äôm resetting like a damn computer.  The organic smell of the river hits my senses like a truck and I do a sharp inhale before peering over to Bruce who is now turned toward me with one elbow on the wall.  ‚ÄúLook I am sorry. I know that you mean well and can be an asset to the team I can see that. But It‚Äôs just been Alfred and I for nearly two years working on this thing. How are you supposed to integrate into the team and be safe?‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt is what it is‚Äù I offer turning around to face the street and lean back as coolly as possible. ‚ÄúI can tell you that on paper I understand the risks that I‚Äôm getting myself into. I know how some of those stories end. I also fully understand that you aren‚Äôt going to always be able to bail me out of things simply because you are who you are.  ‚ÄúBut if you don‚Äôt want me working for you I won‚Äôt be broadcasting anything. I‚Äôm not that spiteful. Besides who‚Äôd believe me?‚Äù  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre oddly patient with me about all of this.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI know‚Äù I laugh with a smile shaking my head. ‚ÄúNo idea why.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWant a job?‚Äù  ‚ÄúI already have one of those‚Äù my hands slip into my pockets and I motion with my head for him to follow me back to the shop. ‚ÄúUnless you‚Äôre offering a supplemental position.‚Äù  Bruce catches up. ‚ÄúSomething like that. Interested?‚Äù  ‚ÄúI might be. How‚Äôs the pay?‚Äù  ‚ÄúNegotiable considering.‚Äù  I shrug ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs something I can pencil into my schedule.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have to make sure you‚Äôre in my good graces in the future or I know four very protective barbers that‚Äôll try their best to kick your ass.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI have no doubt that they wouldn‚Äôt do their damndest‚Äù his tone much lighter than it had been at the start of the conversation.  When we reach the shop the guys leer out the window for any sign of distress on my part and I wave them all off. The smell of product Barbasol and Dozer‚Äôs burnt coffee swirl in the air but at least the cool breeze from the river is doing something for the heat.  Bruce apologizes again and shakes my hand rather officially in view of his jury.  An idea sparks in my mind when he turns to leave. ‚ÄúQuestion for you.‚Äù  ‚ÄúShoot.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhen you were in Paris on your ‚Äòsojourn‚Äô‚Äù I add finger quotes in the air ‚ÄúDid you meet Lucius Fox?‚Äù  Bruce‚Äôs eyes shift from side to side and he takes a step back towards me. ‚ÄúI did. He‚Äôd worked for my father at one point I just happened to be in the right place at the right time and stopped a mugging. I try to be a good upstanding citizen when I can be. Why?‚Äù  ‚ÄúSomething for you to think about later I suppose.‚Äù  There is a small hum that rattles in his chest paired with a knowing nod before he turns on his heel and heads for his car. ‚ÄúAlfred expects you for dinner after work this evening. I‚Äôll inform him that you‚Äôre coming.‚Äù  ‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù  Cujo watches from the doorway as Bruce slides into his car and drives off. When I turn to look at him there‚Äôs an air of skepticism about him and I can‚Äôt help but wonder how his intuition must be going off like an alarm bell.  ‚ÄúHe apologize enough?‚Äù  Crossing the threshold and heading to the coffee pot I dump its burnt contents and begin making a new half pot to get us through the afternoon.  ‚ÄúYeah Cujo he did. He might be a pansy-ass bitch but he‚Äôs not heartless.‚Äù  Irish points his clippers at me and waves them in the air ‚ÄúHe messes with you like that again he has us to answer to. I‚Äôll burn his house down. On God.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôll come to that‚Äù I try and pacify them with my charm and easy smile. ‚ÄúWe talked out our issue like adults and know where each other stands on it‚Ä¶not that we won‚Äôt potentially argue in the future but you know‚Ä¶‚Äù  Jax jabs an elbow into Dozer‚Äôs side and snickers ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs it like being one of us and a friend of Bruce Wayne‚Äôs?‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhat do you mean?‚Äù Cujo leans forward on the counter listening intently.  ‚ÄúAll I mean is that dude‚Äôs richer than God right? And I ain‚Äôt ever seen a single tabloid where he‚Äôs got a circle of friends around him like us ya know? But then Chase winds up in Gotham and now Wayne‚Äôs nearly a regular down at the shop checking in on her.  ‚ÄúEither that or he thinks she‚Äôs fine as hell.‚Äù  Dozer shoves Jax playfully across the room the shop erupting into a roar of laughter. I wipe tears from the corners of my eyes wheezing and sputtering while I try to regain some semblance of control over this conversation.  ‚ÄúWell God knows if I wasn‚Äôt going to go on a date with Dozer after he so valiantly saved my life Wayne‚Äôs not got a chance.  ‚ÄúBesides he‚Äôs not that bad honestly. Imagine growing up and having to second guess every single interaction and friendship you had because you had money status or the Wayne name. How many people tried to take advantage of that after his parents died you think? If anything he probably appreciates the fact I‚Äôm honest and call him out on his bullshit.‚Äù  ‚ÄúGirl where were you when we were growin‚Äô up‚Äù Irish hollers from his chair. ‚ÄúCan you imagine how much trouble we wouldn‚Äôt have gotten in to had she been around? Damn.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThat or we woulda just ignored her and done it anyway‚Äù Jax laughs and dabs up Irish.  Cujo shakes his head and pours himself a coffee. ‚ÄúNah. The way y‚Äôall wrapped around her finger now? You‚Äôda been done for when we were young. Woulda done anything she wanted. You woulda been a bunch of choir boys and I wouldn‚Äôt have had to bail your asses out of so much of that hood shit.  ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs more than meets the eye with Chase boys. Probably always will be. A lady of mystery. Our lady of mystery.‚Äù  I pour my own cup of coffee and clink it off of Cujo‚Äôs with a smile ‚ÄúI‚Äôll drink to that.‚Äù

post_body: To the characters we make that are women:   I love you. You deserve to be wrong and right and face the consequences of being either one.   be ugly or pretty without it being ensconced with another character‚Äôs development i hope you hate and love things and there‚Äôs not a moral superiority there within the conflict.  I hope the things you care about are specific and personal with genuine reasons that arent what‚Äôs simply expected of your role in a character.  I hope your attractiveness in body and mind isn‚Äôt just a character trait that just happens to make people gravitate to you. I hope you initiate attractiveness be aware of it and take advantage of it when you decide to.   I hope you are written with your own intentions and selfishness even if those intentions are selfless.   I hope you make mistakes and struggle in how to fix them whether it be bc of the inward self or the feelings of others.

post_body: My brain has been struggling to support Newsies brainrot and Batfam brainrot and the result shouldn‚Äôt surprise you.   Two words: Batfam Newsies AU.  I was struck with it halfway through watching a live production of the Broadway version (amazing) but it would probably be more based on the 1992 movie (childhood favorite I know it better. As in I can quote it all to you.)  So hear me out- I think Jason as Jack Kelly. In 92sies Jack Kelly is a fake name so his real name revealed at the end can be ‚ú®Jason Peter Todd‚ú®! But like grew up on the streets no living family watches out for the younger/newer kids frustrated with the system. For him I think Santa Fe would be a lot more metaphorical since I can‚Äôt picture him wanting to leave Gotham but Santa Fe (the song) just is Jason you can‚Äôt tell me otherwise.   Tim as Crutchy and here‚Äôs where more of the Broadway comes in because I love their sibling dynamic in it and it‚Äôs a little less so in 92sies. Still there but not as much. The live show I saw had a younger girl as Crutchy and their dynamic was just amazingggg. Anyway. Maybe he ran away maybe his parents died early maybe they just ditched him whatever. He does this now.   Dick as Davey Damian as Les. Now their personalities don‚Äôt match up quiiiite as well but I think it could be done. If Dami‚Äôs a little younger perhaps. I‚Äôm thinking Dick got shuttled into the orphanage and met Dami and bc it‚Äôs still Gotham the orphanage sucks and they‚Äôre supposed to go make money or whatever. I dunno that‚Äôs the tricky bit.   We can keep Snyder Medda (unless you wanted to put Selina there but I don‚Äôt really see it.) the Delanceys and Weasel and the rest of the gang of newsies as is unless anyone has suggestions for them. I‚Äôm all ears!  I‚Äôd go by the movie for this and have Clark Kent be Bryan Denton the reporter mostly because I can‚Äôt really think of anyone to fit the role of Katherine and definitely not someone I‚Äôd ship with Jason. Plus then Pulitzer can be Lex Luthor and that‚Äôs amazing to me lol.   And finally Bruce as Governor of New York Gotham Teddy Roosevelt! I‚Äôd definitely have him play a larger role. You have Jason/Jack hitching a ride on his carriage from the Refuge and then maybe trying to steal his tires or something later on they talk blah blah blah strike stuff.   Of course at the end of the strike and all the brothers are closer than ever and the nice old Governor is like ‚Äúmine‚Äù   I don‚Äôt know if this is even coherent but please feel free to add your ideas!! If you use this to write a fic (please someone I want to but I‚Äôm so busy maybe eventually) just make sure to credit üòä if there are any Newsies x Batman fics PLEASE link them!!! I‚Äôd love to see it!

Jason (grinning): you do know I‚Äôm gonna hold this against you for like the next 2 months right  Bruce: (groans into his hands)         Bruce (walking into the living room): hey have you read through the files I gave you yesterday?   Dick: (confused cause he took a day off to surprise Bruce) ?  Bruce: so?  Dick: er‚Ä¶ no?   Bruce: Dick?? What are you doing here?         Bruce (walks into the kitchen with a fresh concussion): Jason? I thought you were on a mission with the outlaws?   Tim: (frozen through mid fridge raid having assumed they were past Bruce calling him Jason since yk. He‚Äôs a shit brickhouse now and Tim is well obviously not): uh?  Bruce: *turns around and leaves*     Bruce: Oh hey Cass when did you arrive from Babs‚Äô?   Damian: (slowly turns around in the black hoodie he‚Äôs wearing) we‚Äôre not even the same gender  Bruce: (under his breath) yeah but the same height

post_body: According to the 1976 DC Super Calendar July 11th marks the day the classic transformation of the Joker occurred first appearing in Bill Finger Lew Sayre Schwartz and Win Mortimer‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Man Behind the Red Hood!‚Äù published in 1951‚Äôs Detective Comics #168.   One of the things that makes Bill Finger Jerry Robinson and Bob Kane‚Äôs Joker character so chaotic is the mystery behind him not knowing for certain much of his background. Although modern DC comic books showcase his most accepted origin story in Alan Moore‚Äôs 1988 one shot ‚ÄúBatman: The Killing Joke‚Äù as Joker says in the graphic novel ‚ÄúSometimes I remember it one way sometimes another‚Ä¶ If I‚Äôm going to have a past I prefer it to be multiple choice!‚Äù. In 1976 however DC released a super calendar filled with birthdays and important events for most if not all of the DC Multiverse including facts about the Clown Prince of Crime. One being that on this day in 1951 dressed as the Red Hood he escapes the Batman by diving into a chemical waste vat emerging with white skin and green hair forever transformed into The Joker. Although this calendar is in Pre-Crisis (on Infinite Earths) era with the character‚Äôs background barely known or confirmed these are one of the few aspects DC has set in stone in its long history. üÉèüìö  Where it all began ü¶á

Nightwing Cover Cross Stitch I made a cross stitch pattern based on the cover of Nightwing #78 art by Bruno Redondo.   It‚Äôs a full coverage piece but you could skip the pale blue background if you wanted. It‚Äôs a large piece 200 by 307 stitches. How large yours will be will depend on what size stitches you do. If you do 11 count (11 stitches per inch) it will be 18.2 x 28 inches. If you do 26 count it would be 7.7 x 12 inches. Always add about 5 inches to both measurements so you have plenty of space around your piece. You don‚Äôt want the fabric to unravel and ruin your project. You can cut the fabric down after you‚Äôre done if you don‚Äôt like having a lot of excess.  ALT<!-- more --> The threads I use are all in DMC the numbers from most used to least used are 310 995 3756 3842 437 996 162 3843 738 739 435 and 801. Estimates for how many skeins you need are listed on both the PDF and in the excel file.   Here‚Äôs the PDF file it‚Äôs printable with a chart broken up into 20 pages. (Yes it‚Äôs huge!)  Nightwing Cross Stitch PDF.pdf  And here is the Excel file since I built it in Excel. If the colors and symbols I picked out don‚Äôt work for you for whatever reason you can edit them in excel. My instructions inside it are meant for working with it inside Microsoft Excel I have no idea how to use google sheets so I can‚Äôt help you there. You can download the file from this link and then open it up in Excel.   Loading Google Sheets  Also in the excel file I have four workbooks. The first is the chart with a grid broken into the 20 panels I used to make the PDF. The second is the high contrast chart without a grid the third is the graph in the colors of the suggested thread and the fourth is all the thread information.   If anyone ends up making this I would LOVE to see process pictures! I started mine yesterday and I‚Äôm so excited about it. This is the first time I‚Äôve ever sat down and written up one of my patterns to share so I hope everything is easy to follow. Let me know if you have any questions!

post_body: Pride Are you proud? Dick wondered staring at the cowl preserved behind glass. I‚Äôve ruined myself- completely abandoned my principles and adopted your own.   The Nightwing suit sat in a similar glass case having been there for as long as Bruce‚Äôs cowl had. Both dusty relics of a bygone era.   ‚ÄúAre you proud?‚Äù Dick asked the marble headstone. I‚Äôve destroyed my soul broken down who I am and rebuilt myself in your image.  Officer Dick Grayson retired the same day as Nightwing and both suits cast aside to answer the call of a fallen father.   ‚ÄúAre you proud?‚Äù Dick screamed to the sky sending shadowy bats fluttering off into the night. I‚Äôm a stranger to myself and what remains of my family just like you were.  Tim had long since stopped answering Dick‚Äôs calls Jason- fuck Jay- would never forgive him and even Damian his Robin was beyond his reach. Dick didn‚Äôt even have Alfred.   Are you proud? Dick pleaded with the ghost of his father on his darkest nights you have to be proud you have to-  There was never any answer.

I get my comics at the library primarily. There are 19 libraries in my county and right now they‚Äôre doing a ‚Äúsummer road trip‚Äù to encourage people to visit all 19. On Saturday I visited one of the ones the furthest away from me and found two of the current World‚Äôs Finest collections there. I was so hyped bc I‚Äôve heard such good things about this run (all very true). Anyway I go to check out my books and the librarian says to me ‚ÄúYou know we also have the third??‚Äù I did not know. I said ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt see it!‚Äù and she said ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs because it‚Äôs in a different spot hold on!‚Äù Then she went to get it for me. She told me she used to work for a comic store and we chatted about comics for a bit. Anyway librarians are cool that‚Äôs the moral of the story lol.

post_body: Project: Killcode Origins ‚Äî Rockie  tw:none. yes i‚Äôm serious!  wanna read the extended story? here‚Äôs the table of contents!  ‚ö†Ô∏è THIS IS NOT THE NEXT CHAPTER OF PROJECT KILLCODE THIS IS BACKGROUND FOR ROCKIE.  five years prior to the beginning of project: killcode  <!-- more --> ROCKIE TOOK A FEW STEPS FORWARD CAREFUL NOT TO TUG AT THE CHAINS ON HIS WRISTS AND RUB THEM RAW AGAIN.  The room he was in was small and white and bright and that was it. That was where he stayed ‚Äì a small white bright room. Chained to the floor by chains so big they were probably partly for show. Wearing a white jumpsuit from head to toe with no socks or shoes and no color.  He got food once in the morning; a beige slop and a spoon. He got food once in the evening usually something a little better like soup. In midday he was released from the chains to move across the white room toward the white door to use the white bathroom. Every other waking moment he was chained and if he wasn‚Äôt chained to the floor he was being dragged along in slightly more bearable shackles by a person dressed in white through hallways that were‚Ä¶ well. The same as everything else.   White.  If you couldn‚Äôt tell his life was pretty riveting.  The eleven-year-old had been in the white place for well over four years now. He was pretty sure if he were put back into the real world he would have a brain aneurism from the sheer amount of stimuli around him. Nothing ever happened there. Rockie stared at white day in and day out reveling in the moments where he had some sort of interaction with objects whether that be his soup bowl the toilet his shackles being swapped the change in scenery from one white room to another. It was about all he could do to keep himself sane ‚Äì focus on the little things he got to touch and see and smell and hear.  He was pretty sure stimulation had something to do with child development but he didn‚Äôt seem to be malfunctioning yet.  That is if you didn‚Äôt count the fact that he could siphon superpowers out of people like a human vacuum cleaner.  To his understanding that seemed to be his primary purpose in life ‚Äì taking other people‚Äôs superpowers. It was what the white-clothes people used him for.  With a soft sigh Rockie sat down on the white floor dragging his shackles around to make the soft scraping sound of metal against metal. It was his favorite sound ‚Äì except sometimes when they brought him a glass bowl for dinner he liked to ding his spoon against that. It sounded kind of like bells‚Ä¶ or what he imagined bells to sound like anyway. He didn‚Äôt quite remember the real deal. Although he did remember going to church on Sundays and hearing the loud bells at noon the kind of low sound that rattled his teeth but those were the wrong kind of bells; his bowl sounded more like sleigh bells or a service bell on a desk somewhere.  He wished he had one of those desk bells. It‚Äôd be much more interesting than chains and a white floor.  He lifted his arms and dropped them slowly creating a repetitive clack-clack-clack-clack of each metal link hitting the floor. He wasn‚Äôt sure he could make any new sounds with his chains ‚Äì he‚Äôd been locked up for so long he was pretty sure he‚Äôd exhausted them all. He wished he could hear more.  After a while of the clacking sound he grew tired of it so he laid down sprawled out in the middle of the floor for no apparent reason. His chains were anchored into the metal far from each other so he could really only move a few yards forward or backwards and maybe a foot to either side. He could only use both hands for things like eating if he sat dead-center in the room where the chains gave the most slack. That didn‚Äôt leave him very many options for exploring ‚Äì not that there was much to see in a room so white. (But still walking around would be kind of nice? For him walking in a simple circle sounded fun. Exciting even.)  His internal clock began to tick down and the realization that they would probably be coming to give him food soon surfaced in his mind. Maybe he could get them to talk to him. No one really ever did ‚Äì most of them ignored his statements or told him to stay quiet which was kind of annoying. Although he did appreciate them taking the time to say something even if it was shut up. The silent treatment was something he despised. He wanted to talk so bad. He wanted to interact with humans so bad. Why couldn‚Äôt he do that here? Why wasn‚Äôt he allowed to?  The white door opposite to the bathroom opened at least ten minutes too early which had Rockie sitting up from his spot.  A person in a solid white jumpsuit entered ‚Äì it was an older man. Rockie didn‚Äôt know his name he was never told what it was though he did know this was the man responsible for bringing him meals. (It was a woman who unchained him for the bathroom ‚Äì he didn‚Äôt like her. Her hair stuck up too much to be normal. Not that he knew too awfully much about normalcy.)  He watched as the man entered with no tray of food but his hands hidden behind‚Äôs back instead. Rockie‚Äôs eyes traveled warily with him. They‚Äôd never hurt Rockie there (which was good because the white was torture enough.) but if he didn‚Äôt have something bad why were his hands hidden?  Rockie found himself sliding backwards on the familiar man‚Äôs approach.  ‚ÄúCalm‚Äù The man ordered holding a delicate hand in Rockie‚Äôs direction the other staying out of sight. His icy blue eyes were glimmering with something like joy like happiness. He crouched down in front of the child with a small smile tugging at his mouth; a smile! Rock never really saw people smile and at the simple expression he felt one forming on his face too though he didn‚Äôt know why. Humans were so fluid so exciting so contagious.  He wished he saw more humans.  ‚ÄúI have a gift for you‚Äù The man started slowly his smile only growing glimmer in his eyes brightening like he were talking to some kind of dog he was about to treat. Rockie tilted his head to one side in question ‚Äì adding more to the dog theory when he really thought about it.  ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù The child questioned craning his neck in an attempt to get a view behind the man‚Äôs back. He moved so Rockie couldn‚Äôt see. ‚ÄúA good one? You look happy.‚Äù  ‚ÄúYes a good one‚Äù He replied. ‚ÄúJust for you from my office.‚Äù  Rockie leaned to one side again trying to get a view of it. ‚ÄúCan I see?‚Äù  In one swift exciting motion the food-man brought his other hand forward revealing probably the most peculiar thing Rockie had seen in a long long time. It was a little cube. On each side of the cube were nine little squares all different colors. More colors than he‚Äôd seen in forever ‚Äì red and blue and yellow and green and orange and of course white.  The sight of the little thing alone was enough to make Rockie‚Äôs face split into a wide grin his fingers twitching in anticipation like a bull ready to run. ‚ÄúCan I touch it?‚Äù  ‚ÄúThis is called a Rubik‚Äôs cube. It‚Äôs a handheld puzzle‚Äù The man explained. He then took the cube in both hands and began to turn it one piece at a time shifting where the colors were on the outside. ‚ÄúThe goal is to get all the green squares on one side all the red on another and the blue and so on to make it a uniform cube with only one color on every side.‚Äù  Rockie‚Äôs eyes moved with him as the man worked the puzzle turning and twisting it swapping the colors out.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never solved one myself‚Äù He continued setting the cube on the floor a taunting distance away as Rockie couldn‚Äôt reach it with his shackles. ‚ÄúThis is yours now. But only if you do something for me first.‚Äù  The child nodded readily eyes still trained on the little most-colorful-thing-he‚Äôd-ever-seen-ever.  ‚ÄúI am going to unchain you and take you to the siphon room. There are many patients in there for you today so you might feel a little tired afterwards‚Äù The man smiled. ‚ÄúJust remember that you are doing something good for them‚Ä¶ making a difference in their lives so that they can live it normal and free beyond walls like these.‚Äù  Rockie nodded but kept looking at the cube. ‚ÄúSometimes I wish I could take my own superpowers away.‚Äù  ‚ÄúNone of that now‚Äù The man frowned. ‚ÄúYour powers have a purpose. You‚Äôre changing lives. Saving them.‚Äù  ‚ÄúBut what if they wanted to keep their powers?‚Äù The boy asked his eyes flicking up to the man in the room. Something in the air seemed to change something on his face shifted.  ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt‚Äù He answered curtly. ‚ÄúMetahumans are abominations that need to be destroyed.‚Äù  Rockie blinked once twice and then looked down at the white floor.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre keeping them from that fate. You‚Äôre turning them back into normal people. Giving their lives back‚Äù  A moment of silence passed and the child tapped one finger on the floor. ‚ÄúDo I need to be destroyed?‚Äù  A beat passed.  ‚ÄúYes. But not until your time of saving is done‚Äù The man replied. He reached down and with a key he pulled from a pocket when Rockie wasn‚Äôt looking unlocked his shackles. ‚ÄúNow come on; let‚Äôs go set some people free shall we? I‚Äôll even let you walk without chains this time.‚Äù  Rockie with one last look at the little cube followed the man out of the room.  White halls and a few moments of quiet and they were in the siphon room. It was just like Rockie‚Äôs white a bland except it had a dozen big metal chairs spaced out in it for people who didn‚Äôt want to cooperate with metal clasps that held them down. Currently they were all full of writhing patients.  The siphon room had some kind of technology in the walls that kept metahumans from using their powers within ‚Äì Rockie wasn‚Äôt quite sure about it really but he knew the technology was from a man named Dr. Keene who had delightedly used him as a test subject for the technology once. It hadn‚Äôt been terrible he was simply asked to siphon over and over and over again until the science man got it right and Rockie couldn‚Äôt siphon anymore. But something about him had been strange‚Ä¶ heavy dark. Like he made the air thick around him when he moved like he had a storm cloud that went with him everywhere.  Rockie only saw him once more after that when he was given a new jumpsuit that supposedly would let him use his powers within the walls while the others couldn‚Äôt. (Newsflash; it worked. Which was why he was still having to do his job today.)  ‚ÄúTake your pick of where to start do them all‚Äù The man ordered propping himself up near the door. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right here if you need me.‚Äù  Rockie nodded once glancing at the dozen people in the room. Most were children his age or younger but a few were teenagers and he spied one adult in the back corner too all with a single sleeve rolled up. They were trying to break out of the clasps that held them to the chairs some of the kids crying some of the older ones growling about police and lawyers and stuff ‚Äì Rockie didn‚Äôt really know what it all meant. Instead of dwelling on it he thought about his cube and he dutifully chose who to start with: a boy in the front row whose eyes were glowing a strange shade of magenta.  He was silent as Rockie approached his magenta eyes following him all the way. He didn‚Äôt seem that much older than Rockie actually. He might‚Äôve been a couple years older with blonde hair that stuck out like a sore thumb in the room. He squirmed lightly the closer he got.  ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry I don‚Äôt think it hurts‚Äù Rockie muttered. ‚ÄúIt only takes a second.‚Äù  The boy scowled at him. ‚ÄúMy parents didn‚Äôt even ask if I wanted to keep them they just sent me here.‚Äù  Rockie could‚Äôve paused but he didn‚Äôt decide he needed to. He could‚Äôve asked the boy a bazillion questions but he didn‚Äôt decide he needed to do that either. So instead he reached out and gently touched the boy‚Äôs exposed arm forcing the previous statement out of his mind. It wasn‚Äôt his to dwell on.  His hand began to glow and with a sudden wave of cold and weightlessness that entered his body Rockie exhaled. He could feel something strange moving through his veins and one second after he was cold he was so so hot. He felt the tips of his toes leave the cool metal floor and the crawling in his veins continued even as he released the other boy‚Äôs arm.  He grimaced as the feeling became progressively more like snakes under his skin ‚Äì whole snakes like pythons or whatever the biggest possible ones were curling around his organs making it hard to think hard to breathe hard to feel. He peeled his eyes open and he was hovering a few feet off of the floor. All of the fire and cold and snakes seemed to pool in his left hand until it spilled out in a violent burning sensation arcs of loud striking electricity erupting from his fingertips like a firework show with loud cracks! and bangs! The lightning wound up his left arm like a serpent moving from there to his head then his other arm his torso and legs cracking and striking him painfully what seemed like a billion times a second. It felt like he was on fire like he was being stabbed by a trillion knives ‚Äì it was a pain so intense he couldn‚Äôt even make himself react. Bolts of lightning were shooting out from him like he was a storm cloud a human piece of dynamite.  And suddenly it stopped.  His bare feet hit the floor and he stumbled breaths bated like he‚Äôd run a marathon. His whole entire body seemed to be buzzing like he was filled with a million bees all trying to break out at once the screaming searing pain fading to an occasional full body jolt of something fiery.  The boy in the chair hadn‚Äôt moved an inch but his scowl was deeper now.  ‚ÄúLooks like it hurt you way more than it hurt me. Have fun being electrocuted asshole‚Äù  Rockie with a grimace at the strange electricity buzzing through his entire body glanced back at the food man who nodded for him to continue.  He glanced back at the room at all the eyes that were now on him. Eleven to go.  He was unconscious by the fourth. (And once he woke up he kept going as he was told. One of them had the power of death. That went about as well as you could imagine.)  The Rubik‚Äôs cube was waiting on him in his room when he returned even though he wasn‚Äôt conscious to see it.  ‚Äî  dedicated to @sassenashsworld‚ù§Ô∏è  ‚Äî tag list! (If you want me to remove or add you ask in comments!)  @fleur-alise@sarcopterygiian@flyrobinflyy@skylathescholar @gayboss-too-close-to-the-sun @xiaonothere @beatyoutothatusernameloser

post_body: Like no ok.    We need to talk about the insane amount of autistic-coding in dracze‚Äôs half way across.   Its impossibly good. Detective bruce having Neurodivergent joker under his care even tho hes just as unable to take care of himself as joker is and has his own issues he should deal with. The detective (who lets face it is probably autistic in turn) constantly trying to read into the Neurodivergent‚Äôs behavior to make sense of it sometimes without even realizing it which both helps and doesn‚Äôt because the Neurodivergent obviously feels like hes just a puzzle trying to be figured out by who‚Äôs basically in charge of him and monitoring him no less. Joker retorting back hes not some damsel in distress having to fight in order to not be seen that way snapping when bruce picks his fights rightfully so‚Ä¶ while simultaneously refuses or isnt able to fucking communicate his most basic of needs because he doesn‚Äôt NEED any help!!! He can take care of himself!! and no ones helped him in his time of need afterall why else would he have ended up where he is?? Bruce further proving his point when he shows hes not qualified despite being the most qualified person there could possibly be AND-  And like dont even get me started on the meta aspects too like bruce reading into joker is probably what the reader does as well so when joker calls him out hes also targeting the reader‚Äì GAAAHH ITS TOO GOOD TO BE REAL  DRACZE THE THINGS YOU DO TO ME I SWEAR     Or at least thats how ive read things it might be wrong     Ive just always found interesting how autistic coding in these two is less talked about than queer coding when at least in my opinion they kinda go hand in hand‚Ä¶. i love how HWA deals with both      I feel so lucky this fic is real fr

Ik @cutiecorner hasn‚Äôt been feeling that great lately so I thought I‚Äôd share some headcannons for them (and if ppl just wanna see headcannons as well lol)  These are going to be agere headcannons and are going to be a mix of like just random dc characters but mainly centered around the bats :)  _______________________  ‚ô° Bruce and Hal may squabble a bit when in costume and stuff and may fight but little Bruce absolutely ADORES Hal. Both as Green Lantern and just in general. But he tries to hide it but he Def draws small drawings of both batman and green lantern together or as Bruce and Hal. I don‚Äôt make the rules:)  ‚òÜ Bruce doesn‚Äôt tell anyone about his regression. ANYONE. He does hide it pretty well when he‚Äôs in a different headspace but him in little headspace? It‚Äôs fair game. He‚Äôd likely be a bit easier to read and less careful with things like he is usually.   ‚ôß The only people in the JL that do know about it is likely Wonder Woman Green Lantern (Hal Jordan AND John (*quick side note I hope that‚Äôs the other gls name bc I did forget) Superman was the last one to officially find out just from observing things and a quick Google search.   ‚òÖ Barry also regresses but to the age that around his mom died  ‚ô•Ô∏é Bruce usually is around 1-3 years but goes higher if he‚Äôs not AS stressed or if it‚Äôs just cause he‚Äôs extremely happy and comfortable  ‚ô£Ô∏é Diana Def bought some plushies for the two of them but says it‚Äôs just staying at the watch tower until she can find a place for them but somehow magically they go missing within an hour of being there‚Ä¶.strange‚Ä¶.  ‚óá Hal is actually a switch he doesn‚Äôt regress much but when he does its likely triggered by something negative he doesn‚Äôt tell anyone about it. AT ALL. Even if he knows they‚Äôd be supportive and even help him get through it.  ‚ô§ One day Bruce finds him absolutely BAWLING like this and not knowing what to do he brings him a soft medium-large sized deer plush (that definitely wasn‚Äôt one of the toys Diana bought and mysteriously went missing and definitely ISNT one of Bruce‚Äôs favorite pushes bc it reminds him of Hal) and gives it to him to hug.   ‚óÜ This works really well and allows for Hal to quiet down a bit and tell Bruce that he doesn‚Äôt wanna tell him what‚Äôs going on (yet) but thanks him and Bruce stays with him while he‚Äôs still softly sobbing and hiccuping while holding him. (Bruce Def knows that he‚Äôs little now too though so)  ‚ô•Ô∏é Clark is very understanding about it and even can kind of tell when any of them regress Barry is more open about it but Clark can notice he‚Äôs little even before Barry can. He Def tells little Bruce a bunch of facts about the farm animals and machinery. He also kind of picks up that Hal MIGHT be little at times but doesn‚Äôt push it. He does let Hal tell him about planes and flying when he seems like he is and for once is very excited.  ‚ô†Ô∏é The one time that Bruce and Hal both trigger each other‚Äôs regression by accident from arguing they end up needing to take a break from each other for a while but eventually Hal shows up to Bruce‚Äôs door with the deer that Bruce let him borrow in hand an a reddened face from crying. They both apologize in their own way and go watch their favorite cartoons together! (Both older and modern)  ‚ñ° Little Barry likes to chew stuff like everything and anything. His straw on his cups? Gnawed on until they‚Äôre litterally sharpened a bit. His suit? Holes in the neck part now. Batmans cowl? Teeth marks on the rubber bat ears. Anything and everything is free game. Once he tried to chew the lasso of truth and Diana had to get him a chewy turns out those don‚Äôt last long so Bruce bought him a whole pack.  ‚ñ† whenever hal does go to someone when hes feeling little he goes to Bruce or Clark but he only goes to Clark if it‚Äôs dire and Bruce isn‚Äôt there. He doesn‚Äôt even know that Bruce knows yet he just goes and watches cartoons with him or if shes too overwhelmed she‚Äôll just stay with him and relax a but.  ~I also headcannon that Hal goes by Both He/Him and She/Her pronouns btw  ‚òÜBarry does end up getting a pacifier and tried his best to take MUCH better care of that than his chewies that he takes about everywhere and gnaws on. He saves it for when he‚Äôs calm enough to not chew it as badly.  ‚ô° Bruce mainly has the plushies that Diana bought for him and a few childhood toys that Clark claims that he only brought to the tower for sentimental purposes..although he hasn‚Äôt complained when his old plush cow went missing..he doesn‚Äôt care though he DOES hide them in his room in the tower and doesn‚Äôt take them back to the manor. Well unless they somehow magically make it back with him.   ‚ôß Hal sometimes drops plushes off at the manor along with Clark and Diana. Alfred is aware of this and supports it. Anything that‚Äôll help his son.  ‚òÖ Hal sometimes draws pictures of the whole league and himself and keeps them in a notebook in a drawer in her room in the tower  ‚ô•Ô∏é She Def draws with Barry and Clark sometimes when she‚Äôs bored  Anyways I hope you enjoyed these and I hope they were okay lol :)

post_body: I was reminded of a Thing from the reblogs on the Mermay 03 Prompt Very similar vibes. But with platonic omegaverse and dragons. Gotham? Already cursed to hell and back. But then another curse was formed via the museum bringing in this strange statue. That of course got stolen because solid crystal and gold. Then got broken split in half. And oop.  New Curse.   Now before I get into the curse lemme explain the omegaverse side of things. Everyone is born a secondary gender labeled Alpha Omega or Beta. There‚Äôs also medical conditions where one is neither usually a mix of genetic and hormonal issues. Gotham however is Weird. They have no set scent according to Outsiders. Really? They can shift and switch (Yes there‚Äôs a large LGTBQ percentage in the population) at will. It can take months for someone new to the city but those that have been there for a few generations can do it in hours. For those like the Waynes or other founders who have been there since the beginning of the city? Minutes.  It‚Äôs more than a little unnerving to Outsiders who are used to things staying the same.   But that curse (or blessing as others call it) mixed with the new dragon one. See they can all change into draconic form and do their best to keep that secret. But they also have different forms depending on the secondary sex they are at that time.      <!-- more --> @f4nd0m-fun & @golden-buddle idk if u‚Äôd be interested in this but-

post_body: Project: Killcode Origins ‚Äî Rockie  tw:none. yes i‚Äôm serious!  wanna read the extended story? here‚Äôs the table of contents!  ‚ö†Ô∏è THIS IS NOT THE NEXT CHAPTER OF PROJECT KILLCODE THIS IS BACKGROUND FOR ROCKIE.  five years prior to the beginning of project: killcode  <!-- more --> ROCKIE TOOK A FEW STEPS FORWARD CAREFUL NOT TO TUG AT THE CHAINS ON HIS WRISTS AND RUB THEM RAW AGAIN.  The room he was in was small and white and bright and that was it. That was where he stayed ‚Äì a small white bright room. Chained to the floor by chains so big they were probably partly for show. Wearing a white jumpsuit from head to toe with no socks or shoes and no color.  He got food once in the morning; a beige slop and a spoon. He got food once in the evening usually something a little better like soup. In midday he was released from the chains to move across the white room toward the white door to use the white bathroom. Every other waking moment he was chained and if he wasn‚Äôt chained to the floor he was being dragged along in slightly more bearable shackles by a person dressed in white through hallways that were‚Ä¶ well. The same as everything else.   White.  If you couldn‚Äôt tell his life was pretty riveting.  The eleven-year-old had been in the white place for well over four years now. He was pretty sure if he were put back into the real world he would have a brain aneurism from the sheer amount of stimuli around him. Nothing ever happened there. Rockie stared at white day in and day out reveling in the moments where he had some sort of interaction with objects whether that be his soup bowl the toilet his shackles being swapped the change in scenery from one white room to another. It was about all he could do to keep himself sane ‚Äì focus on the little things he got to touch and see and smell and hear.  He was pretty sure stimulation had something to do with child development but he didn‚Äôt seem to be malfunctioning yet.  That is if you didn‚Äôt count the fact that he could siphon superpowers out of people like a human vacuum cleaner.  To his understanding that seemed to be his primary purpose in life ‚Äì taking other people‚Äôs superpowers. It was what the white-clothes people used him for.  With a soft sigh Rockie sat down on the white floor dragging his shackles around to make the soft scraping sound of metal against metal. It was his favorite sound ‚Äì except sometimes when they brought him a glass bowl for dinner he liked to ding his spoon against that. It sounded kind of like bells‚Ä¶ or what he imagined bells to sound like anyway. He didn‚Äôt quite remember the real deal. Although he did remember going to church on Sundays and hearing the loud bells at noon the kind of low sound that rattled his teeth but those were the wrong kind of bells; his bowl sounded more like sleigh bells or a service bell on a desk somewhere.  He wished he had one of those desk bells. It‚Äôd be much more interesting than chains and a white floor.  He lifted his arms and dropped them slowly creating a repetitive clack-clack-clack-clack of each metal link hitting the floor. He wasn‚Äôt sure he could make any new sounds with his chains ‚Äì he‚Äôd been locked up for so long he was pretty sure he‚Äôd exhausted them all. He wished he could hear more.  After a while of the clacking sound he grew tired of it so he laid down sprawled out in the middle of the floor for no apparent reason. His chains were anchored into the metal far from each other so he could really only move a few yards forward or backwards and maybe a foot to either side. He could only use both hands for things like eating if he sat dead-center in the room where the chains gave the most slack. That didn‚Äôt leave him very many options for exploring ‚Äì not that there was much to see in a room so white. (But still walking around would be kind of nice? For him walking in a simple circle sounded fun. Exciting even.)  His internal clock began to tick down and the realization that they would probably be coming to give him food soon surfaced in his mind. Maybe he could get them to talk to him. No one really ever did ‚Äì most of them ignored his statements or told him to stay quiet which was kind of annoying. Although he did appreciate them taking the time to say something even if it was shut up. The silent treatment was something he despised. He wanted to talk so bad. He wanted to interact with humans so bad. Why couldn‚Äôt he do that here? Why wasn‚Äôt he allowed to?  The white door opposite to the bathroom opened at least ten minutes too early which had Rockie sitting up from his spot.  A person in a solid white jumpsuit entered ‚Äì it was an older man. Rockie didn‚Äôt know his name he was never told what it was though he did know this was the man responsible for bringing him meals. (It was a woman who unchained him for the bathroom ‚Äì he didn‚Äôt like her. Her hair stuck up too much to be normal. Not that he knew too awfully much about normalcy.)  He watched as the man entered with no tray of food but his hands hidden behind‚Äôs back instead. Rockie‚Äôs eyes traveled warily with him. They‚Äôd never hurt Rockie there (which was good because the white was torture enough.) but if he didn‚Äôt have something bad why were his hands hidden?  Rockie found himself sliding backwards on the familiar man‚Äôs approach.  ‚ÄúCalm‚Äù The man ordered holding a delicate hand in Rockie‚Äôs direction the other staying out of sight. His icy blue eyes were glimmering with something like joy like happiness. He crouched down in front of the child with a small smile tugging at his mouth; a smile! Rock never really saw people smile and at the simple expression he felt one forming on his face too though he didn‚Äôt know why. Humans were so fluid so exciting so contagious.  He wished he saw more humans.  ‚ÄúI have a gift for you‚Äù The man started slowly his smile only growing glimmer in his eyes brightening like he were talking to some kind of dog he was about to treat. Rockie tilted his head to one side in question ‚Äì adding more to the dog theory when he really thought about it.  ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù The child questioned craning his neck in an attempt to get a view behind the man‚Äôs back. He moved so Rockie couldn‚Äôt see. ‚ÄúA good one? You look happy.‚Äù  ‚ÄúYes a good one‚Äù He replied. ‚ÄúJust for you from my office.‚Äù  Rockie leaned to one side again trying to get a view of it. ‚ÄúCan I see?‚Äù  In one swift exciting motion the food-man brought his other hand forward revealing probably the most peculiar thing Rockie had seen in a long long time. It was a little cube. On each side of the cube were nine little squares all different colors. More colors than he‚Äôd seen in forever ‚Äì red and blue and yellow and green and orange and of course white.  The sight of the little thing alone was enough to make Rockie‚Äôs face split into a wide grin his fingers twitching in anticipation like a bull ready to run. ‚ÄúCan I touch it?‚Äù  ‚ÄúThis is called a Rubik‚Äôs cube. It‚Äôs a handheld puzzle‚Äù The man explained. He then took the cube in both hands and began to turn it one piece at a time shifting where the colors were on the outside. ‚ÄúThe goal is to get all the green squares on one side all the red on another and the blue and so on to make it a uniform cube with only one color on every side.‚Äù  Rockie‚Äôs eyes moved with him as the man worked the puzzle turning and twisting it swapping the colors out.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never solved one myself‚Äù He continued setting the cube on the floor a taunting distance away as Rockie couldn‚Äôt reach it with his shackles. ‚ÄúThis is yours now. But only if you do something for me first.‚Äù  The child nodded readily eyes still trained on the little most-colorful-thing-he‚Äôd-ever-seen-ever.  ‚ÄúI am going to unchain you and take you to the siphon room. There are many patients in there for you today so you might feel a little tired afterwards‚Äù The man smiled. ‚ÄúJust remember that you are doing something good for them‚Ä¶ making a difference in their lives so that they can live it normal and free beyond walls like these.‚Äù  Rockie nodded but kept looking at the cube. ‚ÄúSometimes I wish I could take my own superpowers away.‚Äù  ‚ÄúNone of that now‚Äù The man frowned. ‚ÄúYour powers have a purpose. You‚Äôre changing lives. Saving them.‚Äù  ‚ÄúBut what if they wanted to keep their powers?‚Äù The boy asked his eyes flicking up to the man in the room. Something in the air seemed to change something on his face shifted.  ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt‚Äù He answered curtly. ‚ÄúMetahumans are abominations that need to be destroyed.‚Äù  Rockie blinked once twice and then looked down at the white floor.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre keeping them from that fate. You‚Äôre turning them back into normal people. Giving their lives back‚Äù  A moment of silence passed and the child tapped one finger on the floor. ‚ÄúDo I need to be destroyed?‚Äù  A beat passed.  ‚ÄúYes. But not until your time of saving is done‚Äù The man replied. He reached down and with a key he pulled from a pocket when Rockie wasn‚Äôt looking unlocked his shackles. ‚ÄúNow come on; let‚Äôs go set some people free shall we? I‚Äôll even let you walk without chains this time.‚Äù  Rockie with one last look at the little cube followed the man out of the room.  White halls and a few moments of quiet and they were in the siphon room. It was just like Rockie‚Äôs white a bland except it had a dozen big metal chairs spaced out in it for people who didn‚Äôt want to cooperate with metal clasps that held them down. Currently they were all full of writhing patients.  The siphon room had some kind of technology in the walls that kept metahumans from using their powers within ‚Äì Rockie wasn‚Äôt quite sure about it really but he knew the technology was from a man named Dr. Keene who had delightedly used him as a test subject for the technology once. It hadn‚Äôt been terrible he was simply asked to siphon over and over and over again until the science man got it right and Rockie couldn‚Äôt siphon anymore. But something about him had been strange‚Ä¶ heavy dark. Like he made the air thick around him when he moved like he had a storm cloud that went with him everywhere.  Rockie only saw him once more after that when he was given a new jumpsuit that supposedly would let him use his powers within the walls while the others couldn‚Äôt. (Newsflash; it worked. Which was why he was still having to do his job today.)  ‚ÄúTake your pick of where to start do them all‚Äù The man ordered propping himself up near the door. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right here if you need me.‚Äù  Rockie nodded once glancing at the dozen people in the room. Most were children his age or younger but a few were teenagers and he spied one adult in the back corner too all with a single sleeve rolled up. They were trying to break out of the clasps that held them to the chairs some of the kids crying some of the older ones growling about police and lawyers and stuff ‚Äì Rockie didn‚Äôt really know what it all meant. Instead of dwelling on it he thought about his cube and he dutifully chose who to start with: a boy in the front row whose eyes were glowing a strange shade of magenta.  He was silent as Rockie approached his magenta eyes following him all the way. He didn‚Äôt seem that much older than Rockie actually. He might‚Äôve been a couple years older with blonde hair that stuck out like a sore thumb in the room. He squirmed lightly the closer he got.  ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry I don‚Äôt think it hurts‚Äù Rockie muttered. ‚ÄúIt only takes a second.‚Äù  The boy scowled at him. ‚ÄúMy parents didn‚Äôt even ask if I wanted to keep them they just sent me here.‚Äù  Rockie could‚Äôve paused but he didn‚Äôt decide he needed to. He could‚Äôve asked the boy a bazillion questions but he didn‚Äôt decide he needed to do that either. So instead he reached out and gently touched the boy‚Äôs exposed arm forcing the previous statement out of his mind. It wasn‚Äôt his to dwell on.  His hand began to glow and with a sudden wave of cold and weightlessness that entered his body Rockie exhaled. He could feel something strange moving through his veins and one second after he was cold he was so so hot. He felt the tips of his toes leave the cool metal floor and the crawling in his veins continued even as he released the other boy‚Äôs arm.  He grimaced as the feeling became progressively more like snakes under his skin ‚Äì whole snakes like pythons or whatever the biggest possible ones were curling around his organs making it hard to think hard to breathe hard to feel. He peeled his eyes open and he was hovering a few feet off of the floor. All of the fire and cold and snakes seemed to pool in his left hand until it spilled out in a violent burning sensation arcs of loud striking electricity erupting from his fingertips like a firework show with loud cracks! and bangs! The lightning wound up his left arm like a serpent moving from there to his head then his other arm his torso and legs cracking and striking him painfully what seemed like a billion times a second. It felt like he was on fire like he was being stabbed by a trillion knives ‚Äì it was a pain so intense he couldn‚Äôt even make himself react. Bolts of lightning were shooting out from him like he was a storm cloud a human piece of dynamite.  And suddenly it stopped.  His bare feet hit the floor and he stumbled breaths bated like he‚Äôd run a marathon. His whole entire body seemed to be buzzing like he was filled with a million bees all trying to break out at once the screaming searing pain fading to an occasional full body jolt of something fiery.  The boy in the chair hadn‚Äôt moved an inch but his scowl was deeper now.  ‚ÄúLooks like it hurt you way more than it hurt me. Have fun being electrocuted asshole‚Äù  Rockie with a grimace at the strange electricity buzzing through his entire body glanced back at the food man who nodded for him to continue.  He glanced back at the room at all the eyes that were now on him. Eleven to go.  He was unconscious by the fourth. (And once he woke up he kept going as he was told. One of them had the power of death. That went about as well as you could imagine.)  The Rubik‚Äôs cube was waiting on him in his room when he returned even though he wasn‚Äôt conscious to see it.  ‚Äî  dedicated to @sassenashsworld‚ù§Ô∏è  ‚Äî tag list! (If you want me to remove or add you ask in comments!)  @fleur-alise@sarcopterygiian@flyrobinflyy@skylathescholar @gayboss-too-close-to-the-sun @xiaonothere @beatyoutothatusernameloser
